content: Does the set of open covers on a topological space XXX with the refinement ordering form a lattice? What about if XXX is finite? The linked page seems to suggest it is always at least a meet-semilattice (?). There is also a 'star' operation mentioned there whose role I'm not sure about. http://www.phy.olemiss.edu/~luca/Topics/top/cover.html

Page 161 of "Topology" by Dugundji (which I found uploaded as a pdf by googling "Dugundji topology") seems to be relevant, although I would have to look at it more carefully. (Numbered page 161 is page 178 in the pdf).
In particular, that page claims that refinement gives a preorder, but not a partial order. Apparently you can have two distinct covers, each being a refinement of the other.
Indeed: consider the open cover of the real line by intervals whose endpoints are rationals with an odd denominator and an even numerator vs the cover of the same form with odd numerators.

If we close the covers downward (so that whenever U is in the cover and V is contained in U then V is in the cover) to get "covering sieves" then we get a lattice structure on these, by union and intersection.
Good to know!! Thanks a lot for the ref and example. So what about if XXX is finite? Is it a partial order then? A lattice? If not, maybe I should just consider covering sieves.

I don't know if this helps, but maybe you can turn the preorder into a partial order? Put two open covers aaa and bbb in the same equivalence class if aaa is a refinement of bbb and bbb is a refinement of aaa. Then work with equivalence classes of open covers - maybe these form a partial order?

I saw a related idea in "Seven Sketches in Compositionality", page 13. A preorder can be thought of as a category, where you have a single morphism from aaa to bbb exactly when a≤ba \leq ba≤b. Then if a≤ba \leq ba≤b and b≤ab \leq ab≤a we have a≅ba \cong ba≅b. So the idea is to switch from a preorder category to an equivalent(?) partial order category where there are no two distinct objects that are isomorphic.

I haven't checked if this works, and I also don't know if it would be helpful to what you want to do.

thanks for the suggestion. I think though, for my application it may be simpler to restrict the class of covers instead of quotienting. Also, I really only care about GOOD covers, i.e. where all nonempty intersections are contractible.
My example is still "GOOD" in that sense, so choosing those doesn't guarantee that they'll form a poset
Right, I see. Any idea on whether finiteness of XXX changes anything?

Consider a two-element set {a,b}\{a,b\}{a,b} equipped with the discrete topology {∅,{a},{b},{a,b}}\{∅, \{a\},\{b\}, \{a,b\}\}{∅,{a},{b},{a,b}}. Here are two distinct open covers: T={{a},{a,b}}T=\{\{a\}, \{a,b\}\}T={{a},{a,b}} and S={{b},{a,b}}S=\{\{b\},\{a,b\}\}S={{b},{a,b}}. Each set of TTT is contained in a set of SSS, and each set of SSS is contained in a set of TTT. I think that means that TTT and SSS are refinements of one another, while being distinct. So, it seems like the open covers of a finite topological space don't always form a partial order under refinement.

That being said, it does feel a little bit like cheating to include {a,b}\{a,b\}{a,b} as a set in open covers of {a,b}\{a,b\}{a,b}. Maybe the answer would change if we didn't allow this sort of thing?

Actually, if we have the set {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c} with the discrete topology, we have open covers with subsets {{a},{b,c}}\{\{a\}, \{b,c\}\}{{a},{b,c}} and {{a},{b},{c},{b,c}}\{\{a\}, \{b\}, \{c\}, \{b,c\}\}{{a},{b},{c},{b,c}}. Each subset in the first open cover is contained in a subset in the second open cover, and each subset in the second open cover is contained in a subset in the first open cover. So, two open covers can be refinements of one another for a finite topological space even when neither cover contains the whole set (in this case {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c}) as a subset.

I wonder if this relates to what Morgan Rogers was saying about closing covers downwards. Notice that TTT and SSS become equal when closed downwards, as do the two open covers provided above of {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c}.

A question that occurs to me: if one has an open cover MMM and one closes it downwards "(so that whenever U is in the cover and V is contained in U then V is in the cover)", is the resulting open cover D(M)D(M)D(M) a refinement of MMM? And is MMM a refinement of D(M)D(M)D(M)? That is, is D(M)D(M)D(M) isomorphic to MMM in the preorder of open covers for some topological space under refinement?
Let's see. Each subset of MMM is contained in D(M)D(M)D(M), because D(M)D(M)D(M) contains every subset of MMM (plus possible some additional ones). Each subset of D(M)D(M)D(M) was either in MMM, or it was a subset of one in MMM (by definition of D(M)D(M)D(M)). So each subset of D(M)D(M)D(M) is contained in a subset of MMM. It seems that D(M)D(M)D(M) and MMM are refinements of one another, if I did this right.

I think that means that closing open covers downwards and working with those ("covering sieves"?) corresponds to picking a skeleton of the preorder of open covers of a topological space under refinement: we pick one open cover from each isomorphism class to work with.
Great analysis---thank you, David!!

A more efficient representation may be to consider only maximal covers, i.e. ones that are antichains. I'm not sure if the intersection/union of two maximal covers gives another maximal cover? If not, it may still have (semi-)lattice structure by taking the class corresponding to the intersection/union. But we need to check that satisfies the universal properties of meets/joins.
Relevant link: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antichain#Join_and_meet_operations

If I'm not mistaken, a maximal cover is the same thing as a maximal antichain in the poset O(X)\mathcal{O}(X)O(X), and according to here, maximal antichains of a partially ordered set form a distributive lattice under the natural ordering . I'm happy about this as I'm considering presheaves on these covers, and a presheaf on a cover that isn't maximal gives no additional information anyway.
There was some lack of clarity about what "refinement" meant that had me second-guessing myself about replying again in this thread, but I hope you got the answers you were after @naso!

I had a thought, and was wondering if it relates to "maximal covers" mentioned by naso above, which I understand to be open covers where no open set in the cover is a proper subset of another. Define an operation UUU that takes an open cover and removes every set from that cover that is a proper subset of a set in the open cover. If MMM is an open cover, then so is U(M)U(M)U(M). Also, every set in MMM is contained in a set in U(M)U(M)U(M), and every set in U(M)U(M)U(M) is contained in a set in MMM. If that's right, then MMM and U(M)U(M)U(M) are isomorphic in the preorder on open covers induced by refinement. I think the covers produced by this UUU operator are the "maximal covers" mentioned above(?).

If that is right, then for every open cover MMM we have two nice isomorphic covers D(M)D(M)D(M) and U(M)U(M)U(M). To my understanding, Morgan Rogers stated above ("If we close the covers downward (so that whenever U is in the cover and V is contained in U then V is in the cover) to get "covering sieves" then we get a lattice structure on these, by union and intersection") that the open covers of the form D(M)D(M)D(M) as MMM varies do form a lattice structure.
For each D(M)D(M)D(M) we have an isomorphic open cover U(D(M))U(D(M))U(D(M)). I would hope that this means that the covers of the form U(M)U(M)U(M) (as MMM varies) would also form a lattice structure. But I would need to think about that.

Intuitively, though, the skeleton formed by taking the open covers produced by DDD should be isomorphic as a category to the skeleton formed by taking the open covers produced by UUU. So I would hope that the covers produced by the UUU operator also form a lattice structure.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

There was some lack of clarity about what "refinement" meant that had me second-guessing myself about replying again in this thread, but I hope you got the answers you were after naso!

Thanks, Morgan! but now I'm worried that I've got things mixed up. The refinement definition I was going with is the one on wikipedia which I think coincides with the one in the in the paper above by Ralph Freese (on page 1) on maximal antichains, where we consider the poset P=O(X) P = \mathcal{O}(X)P=O(X) so that maximal covers are maximal antichains in PPP. ...

Looking at that paper more closely, it's not saying what I thought it was! It's talking about maximal SIZED antichains, e.g. antichains on a finite poset whose cardinality is maximal among all antichains, whereas I want to talk about the set of maximal covers, meaning covers that are also antichains...

On the other hand, and I think this is what David may be getting at, there seems to be a 1-1 correspondence between covering sieves and maximal covers, so since you said covering sieves form a (distributive?) lattice, the same should be true for the maximal covers (although Freese's paper doesn't show that)? But did you have a different refinement relation in mind?
And do you know of a reference for the covering sieves forming a lattice? Sorry for the confusion .

(I also asked this on stackexchange (and also my other question)).

Morgan Rogers stated about that "covering sieves" form a lattice. I would like to check this, and understand it for myself.
A covering sieve is an open cover MMM, so that if UUU is in the cover and VVV is a subset of UUU, then VVV is in the cover.
Let's say we're trying to make a sieve that covers {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c} equipped with the discrete topology. Then C1={{a,b},{c}}C_1=\{\{a,b\},\{c\}\}C1​={{a,b},{c}} is not a sieve, but C2={{},{a,b},{a},{b},{c}}C_2=\{\{\},\{a,b\},\{a\},\{b\},\{c\}\}C2​={{},{a,b},{a},{b},{c}} is.

Let us put an ordering on the open subsets of {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c} by inclusion. This forms a partial order (even more - a lattice). Then, to turn C1C_1C1​ into C2C_2C2​, we put in every open subset of {a,b,c}\{a,b,c\}{a,b,c} that is less than or equal to one in C1C_1C1​. This might be where the phrase "closing downwards" Morgan Rogers used came from, for describing how covering sieves are formed.

Let us now consider the set SSS of covering sieves of a topological space XXX, ordered under refinement. (If MMM and NNN are two open covers of the same topological space then we say MMM is a refinement of NNN exactly when every set in MMM is contained in a set in NNN. Let us write M≤NM \leq NM≤N to say that MMM is a refinement of NNN.) We have M≤MM \leq MM≤M for any covering sieve in SSS. If M≤NM \leq NM≤N and N≤PN \leq PN≤P for covering sieves M,N,PM,N,PM,N,P, do we have M≤PM \leq PM≤P? Every subset of MMM is contained in a subset of NNN, and every subset of NNN is contained in a subset of PPP. So, indeed every subset of MMM is contained in a subset of PPP, so M≤PM \leq PM≤P. So, SSS forms a preorder with respect to refinement.

Is SSS a partial order, so that if M≤NM \leq NM≤N and N≤MN \leq MN≤M for covering sieves M,NM,NM,N of XXX, then M=NM=NM=N? To show this, consider an open set AAA in MMM. Because M≤NM \leq NM≤N, AAA must be contained in a set in NNN. But because NNN is a covering sieve, it contains every open subset of every set in it. So, it must actually contain AAA. Consequently, any set in MMM must be in NNN and similarly any set in NNN must be in MMM. So if M≤NM \leq NM≤N and N≤MN \leq MN≤M then N=MN=MN=M for two covering sieves over a topological space XXX. So, SSS is indeed a partial order.

Next, we want to see if SSS has meets and joins. The meet M∧NM \wedge NM∧N of two covering sieves M,NM,NM,N would be the largest covering sieve so M∧N≤MM \wedge N \leq MM∧N≤M and M∧N≤NM \wedge N \leq NM∧N≤N. So, we want a covering sieve that is a refinement of both MMM and NNN to start with. We can get one by taking the intersection of MMM and NNN. Now, we want to show that if A≤MA \leq MA≤M and A≤NA \leq NA≤N for some covering sieve AAA, then A≤M∩NA \leq M \cap NA≤M∩N. Let BBB be a set in AAA. Then BBB must be contained in a set in MMM, and because MMM is a covering sieve it must actually be a set in MMM. Similarly, BBB must be a set in NNN. Therefore, BBB is a set in M∩NM \cap NM∩N. So, A≤M∩NA \leq M \cap NA≤M∩N.

The join M∨NM \vee NM∨N of two covering sieves M,NM, NM,N would be the smallest covering sieve so that N≤M∨NN \leq M \vee NN≤M∨N and M≤M∨NM \leq M \vee NM≤M∨N. So we want a covering sieve that is refined by both MMM and NNN to start with. We can get one by taking the union of MMM and NNN. Now, we want to show that if M≤AM \leq AM≤A and N≤AN \leq AN≤A for some covering sieve AAA, then M∪N≤AM \cup N \leq AM∪N≤A. Let BBB be a set in M∪NM \cup NM∪N. This set is in both MMM and NNN and so it is in AAA, by a similar argument to that we used above for meets. So, indeed M∪N≤AM \cup N \leq AM∪N≤A.

So, we have at least pair-wise meets and joins. I hope this implies we have finite meets and joins, which would make SSS into a lattice. Intuitively, it seems that the arguments used above for joins and meets for pairs of covering sieves would work for finite collections of them.

Now, for a fixed topological space XXX, let us consider the covering sieves SSS ordered under refinement as a category CSC_SCS​. The objects are covering sieves, and there is a unique morphism from MMM to NNN exactly when M≤NM \leq NM≤N. I am assuming that this category forms a lattice, based on the arguments above. Let us similarly also consider the open covers of XXX ordered under refinement (which is a preorder) as a category COC_OCO​. The objects are open covers and there is a unique morphism from MMM to NNN exactly when M≤NM \leq NM≤N.

We have a map DDD that sends an open cover MMM to the corresponding covering sieve D(M)D(M)D(M), obtained by adding all open subsets of the open sets in MMM. I want to turn this map into a functor. To do this, let us first see if M≤NM \leq NM≤N implies D(M)≤D(N)D(M) \leq D(N)D(M)≤D(N). Let AAA be a set in D(M)D(M)D(M). Then AAA is a subset of a set in MMM. Let A′A'A′ be a set in MMM that contains it. Then A′A'A′ is contained in a set in NNN; call this A′′A''A′′. Then A′′A''A′′ is in D(N)D(N)D(N). Because D(N)D(N)D(N) is a covering sieve, all of the subsets of A′′A''A′′ are in D(N)D(N)D(N). In particular, A′A'A′ is in D(N)D(N)D(N), and therefore AAA is contained in D(N)D(N)D(N). So, indeed D(M)≤D(N)D(M) \leq D(N)D(M)≤D(N).

Now let us extend D:CO→CSD: C_O \to C_SD:CO​→CS​ to a map on morphisms as well as objects. If fff is the unique morphism from MMM to NNN, then define D(f)D(f)D(f) to be the unique morphism from D(M)D(M)D(M) to D(N)D(N)D(N). This exists because M≤N  ⟹  D(M)≤D(N)M \leq N \implies D(M) \leq D(N)M≤N⟹D(M)≤D(N). I believe that DDD is a functor. Without checking carefully, it intuitively sends identity morphisms to identity morphisms, it respects sources and targets of morphisms, and it respects composition by the uniqueness of the morphisms between the objects.

Now, we want to consider a different kind of open cover: where each open set in a cover of this kind contains no proper subsets that are also in that cover. I will call these "maximal" open covers (I hope this is what naso means by a maximal open cover). Let UUU send an open cover MMM to its corresponding maximal open cover U(M)U(M)U(M), by removing sets that are proper subsets of other sets in the cover. (We will see later that this actually doesn't work!)

Let CMC_MCM​ be the category of maximal open covers ordered by refinement. This is a preorder, and we are interested to see if it has additional structure. Let us first see if M≤NM \leq NM≤N implies U(M)≤U(N)U(M) \leq U(N)U(M)≤U(N) for open covers MMM, NNN. Let AAA be a set in U(M)U(M)U(M). Then AAA is a set in MMM, and is therefore contained in a set in NNN. Let A′A'A′ be the set in NNN that contains it. Then I would like to conclude that A′A'A′ is contained in some set A′′A''A′′ in NNN that is not contained in another set also in NNN. However, I could imagine an open cover where this isn't the case. This seems like a problem.

To avoid this problem, let CM′C_M'CM′​ be the category with objects given by maximal open covers and morphisms corresponding to the ordering by refinement, with an additional restriction on the open covers allowed as objects. We only allow maximal covers MMM where every set AAA in the cover is a subset of some set A′A'A′ in the cover that is not the proper subset of any other set in the cover. This is still a preoder.
Let us also create a modified form of COC_OCO​, and call it CO′C_O'CO′​. The objects of CO′C_O'CO′​ are open covers of our topological space XXX, with the additional requirement that each open cover MMM in CO′C_O'CO′​ satisfies the following: for every set AAA in MMM, there exists a set A′A'A′ in MMM containing AAA so that A′A'A′ is not the proper subset of a set in MMM.
Now, define a map U′:CO′→CM′U': C_O' \to C_M'U′:CO′​→CM′​ that sends open covers to their corresponding maximal cover by removing sets that are the proper subset of sets in the open cover. Notice that the U:CO→CMU: C_O \to C_MU:CO​→CM​ we define above actually didn't make sense. If MMM was an open cover consisting of infinitely nested open sets with no largest open set, then U(M)U(M)U(M) would have been the empty set, which would not have been a cover of (a non-empty) XXX. Now, however, we should avoid this problem, as we are only removing sets that are proper subsets of those we keep.

Now we can see if U′U'U′ preserves the ordering of refinement. If M≤NM \leq NM≤N in CO′C_O'CO′​, is U′(M)≤U′(N)U'(M) \leq U'(N)U′(M)≤U′(N)? Let AAA be a set in U′(M)U'(M)U′(M). Then AAA is a set in MMM, and is therefore contained in a set A′A'A′ in NNN. This set A′A'A′ is contained in some set A′′A''A′′ also in NNN so that A′′A''A′′ is not the proper subset of some set in NNN (because we are working in CO′C_O'CO′​). Then A′′A''A′′ is contained in U′(N)U'(N)U′(N) and also contains AAA, which means that an arbitrary set AAA in U′(M)U'(M)U′(M) is contained in some set in U′(N)U'(N)U′(N). So U′(M)≤U′(N)U'(M) \leq U'(N)U′(M)≤U′(N). I think this makes U′U'U′ into a functor U′:CO′→CM′U': C_O' \to C_M'U′:CO′​→CM′​.

Next, I would like to relate CM′C'_MCM′​ and CSC_SCS​. Define a map F:Obj(CM′)→Obj(CS)F: Obj(C'_M) \to Obj(C_S)F:Obj(CM′​)→Obj(CS​) that sends a maximal open cover MMM to its corresponding sieve F(S)F(S)F(S). If M≤NM \leq NM≤N in CM′C'_MCM′​, do we have F(M)≤F(N)F(M) \leq F(N)F(M)≤F(N)? Yes - we saw earlier that this holds for MMM and NNN any open covers, not just maximal ones. So, I think we have a functor F:CM′→CSF: C'_M \to C_SF:CM′​→CS​.

We also have a map G:Obj(F(CM′))→Obj(CM′)G: Obj(F(C'_M)) \to Obj(C_M')G:Obj(F(CM′​))→Obj(CM′​) that sends a covering sieve to its corresponding maximal cover. To check this makes sense, we need to check that each open cover MMM in F(CM′)F(C'_M)F(CM′​) satisfies the following property: any open set AAA in MMM is contained in a open set A′A'A′ in MMM where A′A'A′ is not the proper subset of any set in MMM. This will be satisfied, since this property is satisfied for any open cover MMM in CM′C'_MCM′​, and forming the covering sieve only adds subsets of sets already present. Then we can set GGG to be the restriction of U′:CO′→CM′U':C_O' \to C'_MU′:CO′​→CM′​ to F(CM′)F(C'_M)F(CM′​). Because U′U'U′ is a functor, I think that means that if M≤NM \leq NM≤N in F(CM′)F(C'_M)F(CM′​), then G(M)≤G(N)G(M) \leq G(N)G(M)≤G(N), and so we can extend GGG to be a functor G:F(CM′)→CM′G: F(C'_M) \to C_M'G:F(CM′​)→CM′​.

Now, I want to know if (G∘F)(M)=M(G \circ F)(M) =M(G∘F)(M)=M for a maximal cover MMM. I think this should be the case: we add in extra sets that are subsets of sets in the cover with FFF, and then we remove them with GGG. Do we also have (F∘G)(M)=M(F \circ G)(M)=M(F∘G)(M)=M for a covering sieve in F(CM′)F(C'_M)F(CM′​)? The process of making the maximal open cover works nicely because we are working in F(CM′)F(C'_M)F(CM′​), intuitively I think we do have (F∘G)(M)=M(F \circ G)(M) = M(F∘G)(M)=M. I think this means that F∘GF \circ GF∘G and G∘FG \circ FG∘F are both identity functors. If this is right, I think that means that CM′≅F(CM′)C'_M \cong F(C'_M)CM′​≅F(CM′​). So, the category of "nice" maximal open covers of a topological space XXX is isomorphic to the category of sieves corresponding to these.

To continue this line of thought, I would then want to see if F(CM′)F(C'_M)F(CM′​) somehow inherits a lattice structure from CSC_SCS​. If it did, then CM′C'_MCM′​ should also be a lattice, and so we would have a lattice structure on the "nice" maximal open covers. However, I need to take a rest here.

To summarize: (1) maximal open covers and sieves seem related, but it's not as close a relationship as I thought; (2) there are some open covers for which the procedure "remove sets that are subsets of other sets in the cover" does not produce maximal open covers

(Other questions: might there be some kind of adjoint relating CM′C'_MCM′​ and CSC_SCS​? And is CM′C'_MCM′​ really different from CMC_MCM​?)

General disclaimer: There could be lots of mistakes in the above. I haven't checked it carefully, and may or may not do so in the future. Hopefully there is something here of interest to naso, though!

Under some assumptions about the "niceness" of the covers we are working with, I now have a guess for what the join of two maximal open covers should be. Let MMM and NNN be two maximal open covers. Then maybe M∨N=U(D(M)∪D(N))M \vee N = U(D(M) \cup D(N))M∨N=U(D(M)∪D(N)) where DDD maps a maximal open cover to its corresponding covering sieve, and UUU maps a (nice enough) covering sieve to its corresponding maximal open cover.
I don't know if this actually works. The idea is to try and grab the join from the world of sieves.
